title: DVD/VCD Audio Languages
content:
Hi, i was just wondering, is there like a site where you can download the audio in your language?

Most DVD's are in english and or russion/greek etc. So what about the other languages?

title: Re: DVD/VCD Audio Languages
content:
I really doubt that. Getting the audio tracks into another language would require a lot of voice actors (preferably good ones as well so one can actually listen to them) and most likely the original movie files/tapes without the voice tracks so the new voices could be added properly. I really don't think there are such sites.3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: DVD/VCD Audio Languages
content:
Warning: Not the answer you wanted to hear... not really an answer to the question either, just my opinion following! [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]

There should be quite a few places (I'm not really deeply into this) where you can download (textual) sub titles though.
Personally I tend to prefer that... make that WAAAAY prefer that over Dutch dubbing.
We're a small country, so there's only about 10 voice actors (there's more, but it doesn't feel like it) doing all the films, cartoons, video games, &c., so it gets annoying to hear 3 characters in 1 film all have the same voice, and hearing him/her again in a completely unrelated cartoon, really quickly.

Also, even if I don't understand a single word of say Japanese, a lot would still be lost in translation when dubbed.
I'd rather have the English than the Dutch dub, but I'd still rather have subtitles and the original audio track.
Voice actors interprate the original actors, and not always well enough.Retodon8
